Thanks for being just steps from Muni stops and letting me be able to run in and just by a couple donut holes for under a $1!  I loves me donut holes.  For some reason I've always enjoyed the middle of lots of pastries ... cookies, donuts, cake, brownies ... I'm not an "edge" type person.

Sugary, doughy goodness.  I should stop here again soon.  So much better than Safeway ...
author: imelda j.

description:
24 Hr donuts ftw. Speaking of which, brb, it's 2am.

Yes, it's cash only, but how much are donuts going to run you? Sheesh.

This place is so close I stumble out of bed, grab some tasty treats and I'm back grubbing on donuts before I know it.

It only looses a point because in the wee hours the selection gets a little limited. I know, what do I expect? Otherwise the donuts I've tried at various weird hours have always been fresh.

If you really wanted to you could sit at the counter in the window and wave at the light rail passengers while chomping away. I've never done this but the thought just occurred. The store is right on the corner of 9th and Judah where the N-Line makes it's turn.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I'm not really that fond of donuts, but this corner coffee place has a place in my heart. I lived right around the corner from here, and it's the only place in the inner sunset open all night. The owner and his wife are kind people, and they make everything right there. 

I like just walking by this place and looking in at the people looking out. 

If you are an insomniac, a maniac programmer, a people watcher, recently homeless, a novel writer, a drunk, or have a job that starts at 4am...this is the place for you.

*bonus* If you sit at any of the windows seats, you can pick up about 10 open wireless access points. The only 24 hour internet cafe I know of!
author: rob k.

description:
While housesitting a friend's apartment nearby and needing some breakfast and coffee, I decided to walk on over. The environment looks fairly comfortable, really - it's like that place in the movies where people sit down with a cup of coffee, a newspaper and a big red Sharpie and set to work looking for job postings in the classifieds. Not to say it's lowbrow - Donut World just doesn't make any assumptions about you, except that maybe you have some money and want to turn some of it into donuts, and then maybe want to sit down and eat them.

The coffee is wanting. I mean, I drank it, but I can do better at home. The fact is, though, as other reviewers have said, this is not Starbucks, nor is it Krispy Kreme. And it doesn't come with those prices, either. $7 for half a dozen and a large coffee? Yes please. But I probably won't walk here again expressly for their fare ... next time, I'll likely just be getting a few donut holes and an OJ to hold me over while I wait for the N-Judah.

Also they have one of those old-fashioned (but not actually old, in this case) neon advertising clocks that keeps time and says something about it being Donut Time. I like this.

All told, this is just a Place, you know? It's there for you 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and they have donuts if you want. It's good to have such Places. Donut World is worth patronizing just for that.
author: Luke M.

description:
Donuts at 3am when nothing else is open in the area and you are starving and under the influence.

Can you really ask for too much more than that?  Nope.
author: daniel m.

description: Crazy good. Love this place and its donuts. Cant beat the fact its open 24/7
author: Jack M.

description:
There are 3 reasons why I give Donut World 4 stars:
1. Its open 24 hours- AMAZING for sleepy SF. 
2. The location is a great shelter to wait for the N-Judah, 44, 43 and 6 bus. Great place to people watch! 
3. The self serve coffee is super cheap ($1.35 for a LARGE COFFEE) and pretty good. And you can add all the cream and sugar you want. They often have at least 3 to 4 varieties on hand. The hazelnut flavor is the best. 

FYI: the ambiance does need some major help. The chairs are incredibly uncomfortable (no booths to lounge in) and there are only 2 very small round tables to sit at with larger groups.

Oh and the donuts are okay.
author: Judy L.

description:
Still Best in SF!

I was referred by yelpers to Bob's (pretender to the throne) in the shitty 'Loin, and realized they must only be good immediately after their midnight baking run.  DW always has a good selection, are bigger, and seem to be fresh at all times of the day, and you certainly don't need to be wasted to appreciate them!
author: Ari M.

description:
We hit this place up last night after hanging out at a couple bars in Inner Sunset.  Unwilling to wait the 20 minutes for the fresh batch, I got a glazed old fashioned and my roommate got the oft-Yelp-recommended crumb.

Neither of us are donut connoisseurs or very picky, but I'm telling you - these things were good.  I would say it's probably the best glazed old fashioned I've had.  I will be taking a dozen of these back to Boise for my mom's birthday (she's a sucker for old fashioned).

The amazing part is that we had them at about as old as they get (right before the new batch) and they were still amazing.  And at a cheap $0.75 a piece, I may be the newest Donut World addict.
author: Nate L.

description:
Donut holes here are terrible.  They were soft and the glaze coating was thin and mushy.  I hate mushy stuff.

Their "chocolate" tastes like brown colored sugar, too.

Coffee was.... let's just say I had to go to Starbucks afterward.

However, they really redeem themselves with their Apple fritters, which are off the hook.  The French Cruller is about par, and the Old Fashioned donuts are very good.  Plus they're open 24 hrs.
author: Jin D.

description:
no-frills happy place of fried carbs that opens 24 hours. mmm. 

apple fritters the size of my face. they're quite substantial in weight too, you will not be disappointed when you bite into them. none of that airy, too many air pockets nonsense. this is pretty dense stuff. crispy and sweet exterior, nicely, thickly glazed. chewy in a firm, pillowy way. little squares of apples in between bites. i would recommend sharing this with another person, because even then you'd still feel full but without hating yourself. good stuff, get this.

i have not been disappointed with their donuts, they're in pretty traditional/basic flavors, but that's what i personally prefer anyway. never thought i'd enjoy an old-fashioned donut until i had one here. it wasn't too dense, but not light either. the texture was just nice. the other donuts were yummy too, airy and light but without leaving you with a shortchanged feeling, like you paid for the excessive air folded into the dough instead of the ingredients themselves.

can't remember the names of the other items that i've chosen randomly from behind the glass, but i have not been disappointed thus far. the buttermilk something something (unfilled) was quite good. basic, but the flavor comes through well.

my friends love the filled custard confection with the maple-glazed top. i'm just waiting for the day i choose to jog 15 miles and then get this bad boy.

the items are cheap, the taste is great. awesome for the occasional indulgence. cash only!
author: Eliza D.

description:
Donut World: Not so much a classic institution tasked with serving piping-fresh donut-y goodness as it is a portal into another lifetime- where it achieves another name altogether- "the donut shop of broken dreams".

How many times have I been riding around the corner from 9th onto judah st on the N - pondering to myself some deep thought, like trying to undestand the ellusive link of the word "toes" in all Frito lay products...only to see the ghostly visage of Donut World appear out of the frosty sunset fog.
Then you see them- the patrons- looking forlon into that "7 flavors coffee" and you realize, that just may be the last 1.37 they'll ever see. Lost are the happy faces of donut flavored yumminess, and all thats left are the faces of 3 strangers, all eating donuts, looking at the n pass by like  ghost, wondering.....

...oh yeah, the sugared donut and the fritters here are great, as is the hazlenut coffee of the 7 flavors of coffee......just don't stay past 10pm long, or you'll disappear into the fog as well
author: Tim V.

description:
I like-a-the donuts here.
I like-a-them a lot.
Minus one star for no blueberry cake donuts (which I was craving).
A hearty four stars for hella good donuts that remind me of home.
And by home, I mean the South.
author: LaSha G.

description: Just like the small town bakery I used to visit back home, they have a great mixture of all my favorite bakery goods. Love this place.
author: Selma R.

description: I've been intrigued by this place since I moved here.  I finally stopped by here today to check it out.  Nothing special when you walk in, it reminds me of any corner bakery or deli you may have visited before.  There are two big cases in front filled with doughnuts and pastries. Service was fast and friendly, the girl working behind the counter gave me some recommendations.  At first I eyed an almond croissant that looked big enough to feed three people.  Thinking better of it, I picked out a classic french doughnut with maple flavored icing.  Only $1!  You've got to be kidding me, right?!  I think I've found the cheapest and most fulfilling treat in the city.  Next time you're on your way downtown to shop, I would recommend getting off the bus early, picking up a doughnut here, and then walking down to the shopping center.  That's what I'm going to do!
author: Beenish K.

description: This apple fritter is the best I've ever eaten. Now if you'll scuze me, I'm going to watch the world rush by while I finish eating a little piece of heaven.
author: Anton A.

description:
Mmmm...  Donuts...

Yes, I actually quoted Homer Simpson.  But tose were damn good donuts.  And, they're 24/7!  And, it's a cute family owned operation!
author: A L.

description:
living two blocks away from a 24-hour donut shop is both a blessing and a curse.  great, cheap place to pick up breakfast or a quick snack.  this place makes doing weekly laundry across the street at the local laundromat slightly more bearable.  the selection is totally standard donut shop fare, nothing too adventurous.

when i was younger, i was definitely guilty of doing 3AM donut runs at this place.  (fine, i still do once in a while ;D)
author: Alex L.

description:
Ever since I wrote my review of SF Soup Co yesterday and mentioned Dunkin' Donuts, I couldn't stop thinking about jelly donuts.  (Cue the obligatory "Mmmm . . . donut" made popular by one Mr. Homer J. Simpson).

I've been feeling a little under the weather, and I needed a little pick-me-up.  So, on my way back home from the dentist's office, I stopped by Donut World.

It's your traditional, unpretentious, old-school donut shop.  Regular donuts are 75 cents each ($7 for a dozen), fancy donuts are $1.25-$1.50 apiece.  Donut holes are $1.50 a dozen.  Large coffee is $1.60.  Pretty standard prices.

So, I walk in around 9:30 am, grab a coffee pot and pour myself a large cup of Columbian coffee.  Finally, a small Filipino woman emerges from the back room.  Excited, I rattle off my standard donut shop order, like I have done more times than I care to admit: "one jelly donut and a sesame seed bagel, lightly toasted, with a little bit of light cream cheese."  She listens to me very attentively, and then politely says, "umm, sir, we don't sell bagels."  

I wasn't prepared for that kind of a response.  What do I do now?  What do I do NOW???  Before I let myself have a panic attack on the corner on Judah St and 9th Ave, I took a deep breath and ordered a plain croissant instead.

The coffee was good, the donut was average.  The croissant was fresh, but too doughy and slightly under-baked (Is that a word?)  I also ordered a dozen donut holes to go - they were pretty good.

I guess I shouldn't complain about a filling breakfast for $4.45.  And, if I ever need a donut at 2:35 am, I now know where to go.
author: Yan G.

description:
I LOVE DONUTS.  Especially when I can buy them whenever the hell I want.  This is America, people, freedom of choice!

Give me chocolate old fashioneds and maple bars.

That's all.
author: diana s.

description:
I love the concept.  Donuts available 24x7.  Espresso available too!   Family-owned business.  

But here's my tip.  Going there at night means your chances of getting a fresh yummy donut as most every other reviewer seems to have tasted is slim.  My donuts were good, but already a bit stale.

I'm hopeful that things are different when you get a fresh one so I'm going with three stars!
author: J L.

description:
If you go at 3am it is possibly the most wonderful experience in the world.

Totally fresh donuts. Like. So fresh that they are warm.

I was in heaven. I must stay out later to enjoy this.
author: Diego B.

description:
Aww donut world donutt world..
me an my lil cousin made a song about this place
tthis is the spot to come have super cheap goodness and sit in front of the window and look at all the traffic  & people outside 
wat else do u need!!!
author: Isabella T.

description:
The donuts here are FANTASTIC.  

The only reason I knock them down a star is it took 3 visits until they had an apple fritter for me.  I was so bummed time after time.  But when I got that apple fritter, seriously the BEST.  And their cake donuts are delish.  Especially the crumb.

And they have all the standards- maple bars, old-fashioneds, maple with peanut cake, chocolate with coconut cake, donut holes, the list goes on and on.

And a 24 hour donut place is just fabulous.
author: Staci M.

description:
i discovered this place after getting off the 44 bus on yet another cold, foggy day in the sunset. some friends and i ran in and gasped with happiness when we saw all the donuts! they looked so pretty and i was so glad they had old fashioned ones in all sorts of flavors. but first i haddd to get some coffee when i saw that they had kona coffee! love that stuff. so far ive only tried the old fashioned chocolate donut from here, which is delicious - crisp on the outside but still soft and fluffy towards the inside - and with just the right amount of chocolate frosting.

the prices here are pretty reasonable. a small coffee is $1.50, and my friend got a coffee and donut for about $2. not a bad way to start off the morning.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Cheap donuts that's opened 24/7! What beats that?! I remember I used to come here every morning to wait for the N-Judah with my mom to go to Jefferson Elementary. We got to know the owner or one of the workers, and we usually got free donuts! Good times... I'm sure there's a new owner within the past decade. I seldom go to Donut World now, but the memories will always stick with me. I remember getting donut holes before going to school every morning! Good stuff!
author: Edgar G.

description:
A mere 4 blocks from my house, if Donut World ceased to exist, I don't know what I would do.

The perfect late night stop to satisfy your drunken sugar and dough craving.
author: Veronica B.

description: Old-fashioned glazed donut. The best donut in the world. Everything here is so cheap and delicious. A perfect place for a poor student to satisfy the midnight munchies.
author: N T.

description: I have a love/hate relationship with Donut World. The employees are super nice and I LOVE their chocolate crullers. I pass by them on Muni daily and think about their delicious chocolate crullers melting in my mouth, but 9 out of 10 visits they're sold out. When they run out, I vow to never go back but I always do. I've even thought about bring binoculars on the Muni to see if I can spot my favorite donut to see if it's worth getting off the bus. Why oh why don't you ever make enough chocolate crullers to last through the evening Donut World?! 5 stars for their delicious chocolate crullers, 1 star for never having them.
author: Adelina W.

description: It never closes unless Emergency.  It's cold in there to only protect from wind.  Donut are good to eat when hungry.  I assume its cold in there so they can sell coffee and  tea.  There is no restroom.  Recommend they put one in there cause they never close.
author: John F.

description: You have to go at the right time to get freshly made donuts, if not, then you'll be stuck with the old ones. This is just like any other donut shop. The donuts are good, but some can be a bit too sweet. This place is open 24/7 so if you are out late and want a spot to grab a drink or some sweets, this place will be there for you. The coffee is bad. Not bad bad, but it's bad if you are a coffee drinker. It's not bold coffee at all. Pretty watery. The guy that works there is pretty cool.
author: Eric H.

description: This place was open 24 hrs.. and they had a great selection.  Price was great and the people there gave good service.
author: Roger A.

description:
It's sad how familiar my friend and I have become to the people at the register. It's even more sad that we've tried nearly every kind if pastry in the display case. Well, our stomachs don't think it's so sad, anyway...

The hot chocolate is to die for. They really don't skimp on the chocolate flavoring. And if it's a chocolate fix you need, try the chocolate muffin. But don't get the muffin with the hot chocolate. That's overkill. Aw, screw it. Get 'em both.
author: Joseph R.

description: Every time I walked by, which was all of the time, I would crave donuts and be tempted. Finally one day I walked in and got one. I was glad I did because it was unremarkable to mediocre, so as a result, I have never been tempted to go back!
author: Lauren H.

description: Get your favorite fresh donut and lottery tickets here all at one stop.
author: Tina L.

description: The best and freshest donuts in the city.  Go there between midnight and 3AM and you can get 'em freshly baked.  I would go as far as to say that the ones that just come out are orgasmic donuts.  DONUT WORLD 'TILL I DIE!!!! 94122!!!
author: Amir S.

description: Everyone should try their donuts at least once, and why not since the location is right next to the muni station and the price is so affordable? You could spend less than $3 and leave feeling very satisfied.  The donuts are not overly sweet and are very fresh. I finished two of the 5' and one 3' in a flash. (I'm still feeling guilty about having eaten too much and blame it on the Donut World!)  Definitely a place to bring friends from out of town to try their donuts as they taste much better than those at the chain stores.
author: Elle W.

description: Ok, I know donuts aren't good for you.  But, you know, sometimes I just have to have a donut and I have so few vices left.  They have a pretty fair variety to choose from here and the price is pretty good too although they're cheaper by the dozen (which is not a good thing).  I might have once gotten a hot dog here too many many many many years ago (might have been called something else but still was and maybe always has been a donut shop).  French crullers!  And plain old fashions without any glazing or frosting.  For some reason it takes me back to my childhood when we'd visit my grandparents in Los Angeles--we little kids would always wake up real early but had to remain quiet so our parents didn't wake up; grandma would pile us into her car and take us to this BIG donut place, in our pjs.  This way back before seat belts.  I don't remember eating the donuts she got but I do remember that big donut and the early morning runs in our pjs to go there.  It's just nice to have a donut shop in the neighborhood.
author: Kai T.

description: I used to live right up the hill from this place and every time I'd walk by or ride by on a bus or the N-Judah, I'd grab a Old Fashioned and a little milk before I made my way home from work or school. Now I live in Sacramento, so I can't get my fix at 2am anymore. Nothing is open at 2am here! So, when I had to pick my sister up at SFO at 11pm one night, I stopped at Donut World and made up for lost opportunities and... ate an entire dozen! No, I'm kidding, but really I could go for some donuts right now. It's 10:30 and I know for a fact that I can't get a donut  right now anywhere in Sacramento!
author: Michael R.

description: This is one of the best places for donuts in the bay area. Sure it is not Rolling Pin Donuts in San Bruno which is superior in so many ways to the outside interlopers like Krispy Kreme. But a close second is Donut World, one of the few places to make a crumb donut that is great and is beyond NOT SUCKING, and has a maple series that is soooo good. Best of all coffee is cheap and good and it is open 24 hours. And, if they actually have it in stock, you should try their ham and cheese croissant. They are not super cheap but they are better than most of the stuff that's out there.
author: Greg D.

description:
I haven't eaten donuts for years, I mean like 10 years (!) until one late night after drinking.... I was hungry...  it was open.... Then I got my old favorite: The Chocolate Old Fashioned.  It was so damn good.  So soft on the inside and slightly crunchy on the out and so sweet.  And I had to wash it down with milk and I never drink milk!   
Then I got addicted.  And ate them once a week.  Tried to make a rationale reason to have one like, "i'm getting my calcium intake from  drinking the milk."  Now I try to avoid this place, but it's so close to my apt!  The donuts here are irresistible- watch out.
author: A M.

description: Really great, fresh donuts. Service was helpful too.
author: adrian b.

description: I feel like I'm always here. They are open 24/7 and located in the most convenient location ever at the corner of Judah & 9th. The donuts are really cheap and actually tastes good. Kinda sketchy at night.
author: Carlene H.

description:
Open 24 hours.  easy walking distance from the bars.  you figure it out.

I recommend the ham and cheese croissants rather than donuts when you're drunk.  Granted they're both bad for you, but at least there's a semlence of nutrition in the former.  You'll probably feel better the next day.
author: J B.

description:
sugary, yummy, donuts!

open 24 hours!

$7 for a dozen. 

there is a god.
author: Lisa R.

description: Nice donuts... soft, fresh, not overpoweringly sweet.  Prices are decent, although I go down the street to get a hot chocolate to go with the donuts.
author: Alured P.

description:
Late at night, you won't be able to tell if your donut was made last week or last month. Stale. 

But they were open, and a stale donut is better than no donut after enough EtOH.
author: Shahin S.

description: 24 hour donuts? Love it. Before a 4 am snow trip, we stopped by here for some morning snacks...not only do they have a great selection of donuts/fritters/baked goods, they have Raspberry Peach Snapple to boot! (the BEST flavor of Snapple, imo). They've also got some single-serving size milk cartons also, which goes great with the donuts. I love the glazed twists and I tried the cinnamon roll/bun today. It was glazed with a hint of cinnamon and donut goodness baked right in.
author: erica w.

description: I get a donut sometimes when I'm hungry and waiting for the N judah. I've tried the cinnamon crumb, rasberry jelly, and donut holes. The rasberry jelly is alright, a little too much jelly for my taste. I didn't like the donut holes much, way too sweet, but I never really liked donut holes anywhere. The cinnamon crumb is the best thing I've tried. The cinnamon crumbiness is so good! I've gotten cinnamon crumb the last 4 times I've came here. I want to try the apple fritter next time I come here, if I'm not enchanted by the cinnamon crumb once again!
author: Ale x.

description: Hands down, best apple fritters in the city.  I love this place.  Its open 24 hours which is friggen awesom.  The only problem with this place is that its not very close to where i live.  Im so sad. :(  so If you live near 9th and judah, i hate you cause you have the greatest donut place in the world to go to.  Im gonna go weap now....
author: Daniel P.

description: Ok, I have to write an update.  When you go in the morning, their donuts are actually pretty darned good.  Must only be the night time ones that are way bad, or maybe I just hit a single bad night.  The old fashioned sprinkled were great.  The chocolate eclair-looking ones with custard were the only ones that were not so great since the custard tasted chemical-y.  Otherwise, good and inexpensive.
author: Quince P.
